description: From Middle English neygh, nygh, nye, nyȝ, from Old English nēah, nēh, from Proto-West Germanic *nāhw, from Proto-Germanic *nēhw.
Cognate with Dutch na (“close, near”), German nah (“close, near, nearby”), Luxembourgish no (“nearby, near, close”). See also near.

adjectives.description: nigh (comparative nigher or more nigh, superlative nighest or most nigh)

entries.meaning: Not remote in degree, kindred, circumstances, etc.; closely allied; intimate.
examples: Ye  […]  are made nigh by the blood of Christ.
When the Moon is horned  […]  is it not ever nigh the Sun?

verbs.description: nigh (third-person singular simple present nighs, present participle nighing, simple past and past participle nighed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) to draw nigh (to); to approach; to come near
examples: When the charnel-eyed Pale Horse has nighed
